utterances: Oh, it's mixed.

(Unintelligible) at the Olmos Bharmacy here in San Antonio every Friday for about the last two years, and it's just blowing and going.

Sessions festival, which I help (unintelligible) that, and I also (unintelligible) we're in the middle - beginning of fiesta right now and the Fiesta Blues Heritage Series has become a very well-attended festival in San Antonio, that I also helped get that going.

Hi, Mick.
You're on TALK OF THE NATION.
Hey there.
Hey.

I got to play with Taj a few times over there, which is a pure pleasure.
Yeah.
And (unintelligible) days, played with some of the guys in the American Folk Blues Festival.
But I found that in Europe the blues has a lot more cache to it.
It seems to be more popular in Europe than it is here.
I just want ask Guy if he finds the same thing.
What I find is that it is not taken so for granted over around in Europe.
Over here in the U.S., we got so doggone many channels on our TVs, you know.
We have to live several lifetimes to watch all the entertainment that's on.
So, yeah, I do feel a little - almost more cared for sometimes overseas.
Mick, thanks for your call.

And I'm Scott Horsley in Providence.
Netroots Nation is part pep rally, part technology seminar, and - this year at least - part postmortem.
Netroots chairman Adam Bonin kicked off the gathering just two days after the Wisconsin vote, which was viewed very differently in this crowd than it was by the audience at CPAC.
Wisconsin was bad.
This was a gut-punch to our movement.
But you know, as Bruce Springsteen says in the title track of the new album ""Wrecking Ball,"" hard times come and then hard times go.
And they keep coming and we don't go away.
We keep fighting no matter what the other side brings at us.
This movement keeps going forward.
(SOUNDBITE OF APPLAUSE)
Progressive activists are bracing for another tough fight in November.
Zack Pollett works with a group called the Fair Share Alliance in Arkansas.
He says the mood is more one of determination than dismay.
I think there's a sense of realism.
The country is divided and there will be so much corporate money spent, it will give a real uneven playing field.
This week, campaign finance reports showed Mitt Romney and the Republicans raised more than $76 million last month, almost 17 million more than President Obama and the Democrats.
In the face of these setbacks, Netroots Nation is a chance to rally the progressive troops.
Jeana Brown is a former Obama organizer from Screven, Georgia.
All of these folks have the compassion and also being progressive and out of the box thinkers about human beings.
So, for someone like me to come to something like this, it's almost a love fest.
I can let my hair down and talk about anything I want to.
The Providence Convention Center serves as the big tent for this political revival, where a group working to strengthen gun laws sets up shop next to a group working to relax drug laws.
There are anti-nuclear activists, pro-wind activists, and Credo Mobile, which bills itself as America's only progressive phone company.
A Georgia colleague of Brown's was surprised by the wide variety.
So, as we're walking around and he's reading, he said, oh, I didn't know these people were going to be here.
Oh, these people?
Oh, Jeana Brown, these people are just as crazy as us.
We're going to be able to work with these people.
Right.
Another dealer told me the same thing and nobody knows really for sure why - could have been washed away, maybe still being saved against another day.
You know, every place you walked into in New Orleans, carnival has taken over.
Closings are being announced for restaurants.
They're not going to be on open on Mardi Gras.
Those people are going to be part of Mardi Gras.
And Debbie, by the way, I want you to know I do understand that Mardi Gras actually got it's beginning in your adapted home state of Alabama.
That's what they say over in Mobile.
They claim to be the first carnival and the first Mardi Gras, that the French settlers started it there before they moved west to New Orleans.
So all along the Gulf Coast, folks are having their fun before Ash Wednesday arrives.
There you go.
Can you bring us back some beads when you come, Noah?
You bet.
See you after February 20th.
Thank you.
NPR's Noah Adams in New Orleans.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Melissa Block.
A rally in Phoenix today drew hundreds of people marching in favor of immigrants' rights.
The turnout was far smaller than the massive crowds that gathered for a similar event back in April and this time there was a lot more opposition.
Rene Gutel of member station KJZZ was at today's event.
(Soundbite of rally)
It was a familiar scene at Arizona State Capital, hundreds of immigrants and their advocates waving American flags and chanting si, se puede, Spanish for yes we can.
The protestors' signs read stop the war on immigrants and anti-immigrant laws break families.
Elias Bermudez, an activist with Immigrants Without Borders, says the rally was to pressure the U.S.
Congress to change immigration laws.
They need to deal with this problem.
We do have a problem with illegal immigration.
We want to secure our borders, but at the same time we want to have the legal mechanism whereby people can come here legally to work.
Unfortunately, we do not have that right now.
Back in April, the crowd here was considered the largest immigrant rally in Arizona history.
But today's event was much smaller.
And then there were the counter demonstrators.
Michelle Dallacroce(ph) says she is head of a group called Mothers Against Illegal Aliens.
We the people of the United States of America, our life, liberty and our pursuit of happiness is not happening because our border is not being secured.
They carry their own signs, with messages such as this is America, get off my property.
There were even members of the border-watch group The Minutemen Civil Defense Corps.
The counter demonstration turned into something of a campaign stop for politicians running for reelection.
Arizona's primary is a week from tomorrow.
Here's Republican State Senator Jack Harper.
This is not about being a U.S.
citizen.
This is the million-moocher march, and we are not going to let you steal our tax dollars.
But organizers say they expected the counter-demonstrators.
Activist Elias Bermudez even went so far to say that he was glad they were there.
We're not opposed to what they're asking.
We're opposed to their message.
We're opposed to the way they want to handle this.
We are not criminals.
We did not come here to commit crimes.
We came here to provide a service and this country needs our service.
As for the small turnout, organizers say they expected that, too.
They say they've been focusing on registering voters, not getting people out into the streets.
For NPR News, I'm Rene Gutel in Phoenix.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Melissa Block.
In court in Baghdad today, an admission from Saddam Hussein, but not an admission of murder.
The former Iraqi leader is charged with ordering the killing of 148 Shiite villagers after a failed attempt on his life in 1982.
Today, Saddam told the court he destroyed the villagers' farmland as punishment, and referred the men to a court which ordered their execution.
Saddam said that execution was justified.
NPR's Jamie Tarabay reports from Baghdad.
